image.altText: Charlie sitting in front of Michelle looking down the barrel of the lens with a smile while Michelle looks down at him.

props.synopsis: Fertility researchers express alarm at the Victorian government's move to axe its fertility regulator VARTA, which offers free counselling services to families wanting to meet their donors.

title.children: When Michelle decided to meet her son's donor-related sibling, she had no idea how traumatic it would be

image.altText: A woman standing in front of an apartment complex and smiling.

props.synopsis: Alice Springs community leaders are pushing for more accountability from those tasked with addressing the drivers of crime, as residents wake after their first night under curfew conditions.

title.children: Alice Springs leaders seek evidence of long-term plans to reduce crime amid snap curfew

image.altText: A man with two police officers.

props.synopsis: Police say more than three tonnes of illegal tobacco have been seized in raids on properties in Melbourne and regional Victoria. Police allege the properties are linked to the leader of an organised crime syndicate.

title.children: Police seize tonnes of illegal tobacco after raids in Victoria linked to organised crime gangs

props.synopsis: A comprehensive audit will be conducted into all internet-facing technology used by Commonwealth agencies over rising concerns about foreign interference and influence threats.

title.children: Home Affairs boss orders government-wide sweep for foreign cyber threats

image.altText: A red sign with white block letters that read "Sale" in a shop front window.

props.synopsis: Substantial discounts and sales saw Australians spending more on clothing and footwear in May. Although it may be good news for retailers, what does the increase in consumer spending mean for inflation and interest rates?

title.children: End-of-season sales have Australians spending — but it's 'quite possible' it could contribute to a rate hike

image.altText: Generic photos of apartments, balconies

props.synopsis: Australian home values grew by 8 per cent in the past financial year. Here's a breakdown of how much you need to be earning to afford a property at the median value in your capital city.

title.children: Here's how much you need to earn to afford a mid-range home in your capital city

image.altText: Novak Djokovic stands at a microphone and points his finger at the crowd on Centre Court at Wimbledon.

props.synopsis: Australia's Alex de Minaur is in injury strife as Novak Djokovic awaits, Elina Svitolina fights back tears on a sad day for Ukraine, and Taylor Fritz breaks the unbreakable serve on his way to the quarterfinals. Here are five quick hits from Wimbledon day eight.

title.children: Five quick hits: Djokovic gets Wimbledon fans off side ahead of quarterfinal clash with 'ginger' Aussie Demon

image.altText: A man of south Asian heritage in a blue suit, walking about of a courtroom

props.synopsis: A man accused of setting up a sham company used to steal $1.7 million from Australian scam victims has admitted in court to deleting crucial messages.

title.children: 'Where are they?': The bombshell text messages at the centre of a $1.7m scam fraud case

image.altText: A split screen image of damage in Israel and a woman in southern Lebanon

props.synopsis: An Israeli town 1 kilometre from the Lebanon border is all but deserted as the threat of a new war looms. Inside Lebanon, residents are also preparing for a full-scale conflict.

title.children: Thousands of strikes across the Lebanon-Israel border put the region on alert for a new war

image.altText: A young girl sits on a man's shoulders as he takes a selfie.

props.synopsis: The discovery of photos of Australian children in a gargantuan dataset being used to train leading AI models has given rise to a blame game and some divisive questions.

title.children: When photos of Australian kids are being used to train AI models, who is ultimately to blame?

image.altText: A car drives out of the wooden gates of a property at sunset as a mountain rises in the background

props.synopsis: The New Mexico film shoot in 2021 was a quick one – only 21 days to film more than 130 scenes — but the fallout continues three years later, with a new chapter about to play out in court.

title.children: The cast and crew of Rust set out to make a movie about an accidental shooting. They ended up involved in a real one

image.altText: A close-up of Emmanuel Macron

props.synopsis: France's government and new left-wing coalition found a way to stop the far-right National Rally party getting power. But forging a path through the country's political deadlock is a much-bigger challenge.

title.children: How a 'dangerous electoral agreement' kept France's far-right out of office

image.altText: A cockatoo bites the wire of the cage it is held in.

props.synopsis: Australian wildlife is showing up around the world where it shouldn't. Now animal forensics, artificial intelligence and advanced science are combining to combat the trafficking of these creatures.

title.children: Inside the battle to stop the $450 billion crime industry targeting Australia's wildlife

image.altText: Cut ribbons on a fence

props.synopsis: Loud Fence supporters felt they had achieved something "really special" by joining forces with the church to re-do the display, and say the vandalism is devastating.

title.children: Ribbons recognising child sexual abuse survivors cut from Ballarat cathedral fence

image.altText: A man in a grey hoodie and cap looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: Jarrod Hawkins ran into the burning home in Sydney's West in the early hours of Sunday morning, and helped rescue four of the seven children inside.

title.children: Neighbour who ran into fire that killed three children calls on community to rally around family

image.altText: An empty street pictured at night lit up by street lights

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory police commissioner has declared a curfew in Alice Springs for three nights following a string of violent incidents in the outback town.

title.children: Snap three-night curfew declared in Alice Springs

image.altText: A man covers his face using a cloth to shield himself from the sun as he inspects railway tracks

props.synopsis: Earth hits a concerning climate milestone, with data showing global temperatures at or above the Paris Agreement threshold for 12 months in a row. The year-long streak saw thousands of people across Asia, Europe and America facing extremely high temperatures during June — in some cases, over 50C.

title.children: 50C heatwaves across the northern hemisphere drive global temps to 1.5 degrees above average

image.altText: Joe Biden speaks at a podium with two microphones and points straight ahead. A door and flag are behind him.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden continues to fight for his political life, writing to Democrats in Congress and phoning into a TV show to insist he's not caving to pressure to step aside for a younger presidential candidate.

title.children: A defiant letter, a surprise interview and frustration with 'the elites': Biden digs in for another day

image.altText: A man with grey hair wearing sunglasses, dressed in a white shirt and blue blazer with a US flag pin

props.synopsis: Four more of the president's colleagues voice concern about his candidacy for the 2024 election, in a reflection of deepening party division among the Democrats.

title.children: Senior US Democrats join calls for Joe Biden to drop presidential re-election bid

image.altText: For lease signs in a window reflecting a tree

props.synopsis: Higher interest rates and rising rents are seeing a flood of calls and messages to the National Debt Hotline, mostly from younger people.

title.children: Financial stress 'through the roof' as interest rate hikes come home to roost

image.altText: Man clenches his fists

props.synopsis: Rather than move to give young Iranians more freedom, the Islamic Republic has become more hardline. Can Iran's new president, Masoud Pezeshkian, change that? And if not, the why did the regime allow him to run?

title.children: In Iranian elections, few candidates pass the strict vetting process. Why did new reformist president Masoud Pezeshkian pass the test?

image.altText: Adam Britton stands by greenery wearing a green shirt

props.synopsis: Adam Britton, celebrated as a world-renowned crocodile expert and zoologist, was arrested and remanded in custody in 2022. He has pleaded guilty to 60 charges of bestiality, animal cruelty and possessing child abuse material.

title.children: How an 'unassuming' crocodile expert shocked a community with horrific dog crimes

image.altText: LNG tanker leaves Darwin Harbour.

props.synopsis: For an industry entering its sunset years, Australian gas certainly is attracting an enormous amount of attention and money. And yet, the local market is facing gas shortages, despite being one of the world's biggest exporters.

title.children: Why the global sharks are circling Australia's gas export industry once more

image.altText: A woman lies on a green couch

props.synopsis: Seasonal affective disorder, or SAD, isn't just a northern hemisphere condition. It affects Australians too, and you may be more at risk depending on which state you live in.

title.children: How to know when the 'winter blues' might be seasonal depression

image.altText: Satellite imagery of an ice shelf collapse.

props.synopsis: In 1968, an aircraft flew over the Larsen B ice shelf in Antarctica. More than six decades later, photos taken on that flight have been used to create a 3D model of the region's melting glaciers.

title.children: Melting glaciers in Antarctica have been digitally recreated using a trove of historical images

image.altText: Butter on a wooden board

props.synopsis: With global butter prices at record highs, shoppers are hurting and Aussie dairy farmers look unlikely to cash in.

title.children: Australia is importing record amounts of butter at 'eye-watering' prices

image.altText: Two mothers hold their children

props.synopsis: A Russian missile barrage kills at least 28 and leaves 100 others injured in strikes on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities, including a key children's hospital.

title.children: Dozens dead at children's hospital in Ukraine's capital amid Russian daytime missile attack

image.altText: A single dingo lies down on sand

props.synopsis: DNA analysis suggests dingoes breed with other dogs less than previously thought and reveals key populations predate European colonisation.

title.children: Wild dog or dingo? Ancient DNA study suggests there's not much dog at all

image.altText: A photograph of a brown coloured model of a human brain

props.synopsis: Two women who endured decades of intimate partner violence have been diagnosed with chronic traumatic encephalopathy — the first cases of CTE in victims of domestic violence in Australia and two of just a handful globally.

title.children: CTE found in two domestic violence victims who suffered dozens of head injuries before they died

image.altText: A small doll next to a pin cushion on a silk white pillow. A hand with a blue glove places the pin cushion down

props.synopsis: When an archives manager in England stumbled upon a small black doll, she was puzzled. A clue pointed her to Tasmania and a girl called Mithina, who lived almost 200 years ago.

title.children: 'We were floored': How a chance discovery led to the return of Aboriginal girl's 200yo doll

image.altText: A white and blue plane with the word 'BOEING' and the markings '737 MAX' written on its side.

props.synopsis: Boeing has agreed to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge to resolve a US Department of Justice (DOJ) investigation linked to two 737 MAX fatal crashes.

title.children: Boeing will plead guilty in 737 MAX crash probe

image.altText: Man in military holds drone

props.synopsis: A lightweight US-made drone that carries an explosive payload and fits in a backpack will soon enter service with the Australian Defence Force following its successful use on the battlefield in Ukraine.

title.children: Australian military to buy small US-made lethal drones being used by Ukrainian forces
